Journal.Title: International archives of occupational and environmental health

Article.ArticleTitle: On the supra-linearity of the relationship between air pollution, mortality and hospital admission in 18 French cities.

AbstractText: Understanding the relationship between an environmental determinant and a given health outcome is key to inform public health policies. The short-term mortality and morbidity responses to outdoor air pollutants are traditionally assessed as a log-linear relationship, but few studies suggest a possible deviation from linearity. This paper investigates the shape of the relationship between ozone, NO<sub>2</sub> and fine particulate matter (PM<sub>10</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub>), mortality and hospital admissions in 18 French cities between 2000 and 2017.

A multi-centric time series design, using quasi-Poisson generalized additive models, was used. Four approaches were compared to model concentration-response curves (log-linear, piecewise-linear with a priori defined breakpoints, piecewise-linear with no a priori breakpoint and cubic spline).

All the models indicated evidence of supra-linearity between PM<sub>10</sub>, PM<sub>2.5</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, mortality and hospital admissions. For instance, with a log-linear model, a 10 µg/m<sup>3</sup> increase in PM<sub>2.5</sub> was associated with a 0.4% [95% CI 0.2; 0.7] increase in non-accidental mortality. When using a piecewise model with a priori set breakpoint at 10 µg/m<sup>3</sup>, the mortality increase was 3.8% [4.4; 6.3] below 10 µg/m<sup>3</sup>, and 0.3% [0; 0.6] above. Non-significant impacts of ozone were found for concentrations below 90 µg/m<sup>3</sup> to 120 µg/m<sup>3</sup>, with some variability in the identified threshold across the heath indicator studied.

The supra-linearity of the relationship between PM<sub>10</sub>, PM<sub>2.5</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, mortality and hospital admissions supports the need to further reduce air pollution concentrations well below regulatory values.
